titlestmt.titleproper: Register to The Charles Ives Papers
titlestmt.author: Compiled by Vivian Perlis

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 00:01

did.abstract: Music, correspondence and other writings, photographs, and additional materials by and about the American composer and insurance executive Charles Ives (1874-1954)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The Papers are open to researchers by appointment. There are no restricted materials in the collection. Please contact the Special Collections staff to schedule an appointment.
Some of the materials may be stored at the Library's off-campus shelving facility, so researchers should allow at least two business days to have the appropriate boxes paged.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Charles Ives Papers were established in the Music Library of Yale University by Harmony Twichell Ives in 1955.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Charles Ives Papers are the physical property of the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University. Copyrights belong to the composers and authors, or their legal heirs and assigns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: MSS 14, The Charles Ives Papers in the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In 10 series as follows: I. Music manuscripts. II. Literary writings. III. Correspondence. IV. Scrapbooks. V. Diaries. VI. Photographs. VII. Programs. VIII. Writings about Ives. IX. Ives's collection of music by others. X. Miscellaneous.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Charles Ives Papers include music, literary writings, correspondence, diaries, scrapbooks, photographs, writings about Ives, Ives's collection of music by others, and various miscellaneous materials. The music manuscripts, which constitute Series I of the Ives Papers, are described in John Kirkpatrick's A Temporary Mimeographed Catalogue of the Music Manuscripts of Charles Ives (1960) and James B. Sinclair's A Descriptive Catalogue of the Music of Charles Ives (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1999). Series II through X are described in the present register.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Charles Edward Ives was born in Danbury, Connecticut on October 20, 1874, the first-born son of Mary Parmelee and George Edward Ives. The influences on him as a young musician were many and varied--European concert music, American nineteenth-century parlor music, ragtime, other vernacular and functional musics, sacred music, and his father's unusual interests in sounds. George Ives, being the town bandmaster and a well-trained musician, was the strongest influence on young Charlie; the father's favorite composers, among them Bach and Stephen Foster, became the son's inheritance. As a teenager, Ives was the youngest organist in the state and an excellent athlete. Charles was a freshman at Yale College when George Ives died in 1894. The Ives family, although an early and prominent one in New England, was unusual in its Emersonian interests and actions; ideas of transcendentalism and self-reliance were part of Ives's background. At Yale, Ives was not a good scholar, but he held the position of organist at Center Church in New Haven for four years, and he was already composing extraordinarily experimental music that he learned to keep away from his professor, Horatio Parker.

Realizing that he would not be able to support himself and a family with the kind of music he wanted to compose, Ives determined to make his living in business. He joined an insurance firm in New York City, met his future partner and lifelong friend, Julian Myrick, and soon applied his inventive mind to improvements and innovations in the business that eventually made him financially secure and had long-range benefits for his company, Mutual of New York, and for the insurance business as a whole. In 1908 Ives married Harmony Twichell, a nurse and daughter of a prominent minister, the Reverend Joseph Twichell, of Hartford. They devoted themselves thereafter to a life that encompassed two careers for Ives--the successful businessman and the iconoclast composer. Unable to have children of their own, the Iveses adopted a daughter, Edith, and the family lived comfortably in New York City and in a country home in West Redding, Connecticut. Along with his father's musical talents, Ives seemed to have inherited George Ives's weak heart, for in 1918 he suffered a serious attack that left him a semi-invalid and sapped his energies; his composing days were virtually over by 1920, and business activities were curtailed, ending with retirement in 1930. He died in New York on May 19, 1954.

Ives was a thinker and an inventor of ideas. He thought about music, about life, about music and life together, about the common man, about religion, about politics--and he invented new ways of expressing his thoughts in his music. Ives also was a writer, not as gifted in his literary efforts as in music, but with a bravura style and spirit that simulated his music writing. Ives's literary endeavors were also concerned with music and society, the dangers of war, the ugliness of politics, and the insurance business. During his healthy and creative years, Ives wrote and composed with passion and conviction. Considering that he worked only on weekends and evenings, Ives produced a substantial body of music and literature. His music is often termed "inclusive," in that he saw no reason to exclude any style so long as it served to express his ideas. The songs alone number over 200 and include a wide range--from traditional parlor songs to the most outrageously innovative experiments. The music manuscripts are in themselves unusual visual artifacts, often extremely complicated and at times indecipherable, a situation that has added to existing editorial and publication problems complicated by Ivesian traits such as multiple choices for performers, unusual instrumentation, multilayering, quarter-tones, etc. The availability of Ives's music today is due largely to the efforts of several younger musicians who "discovered" Ives in the twenties and thirties, among them Henry Cowell, Elliott Carter, Bernard Herrmann, Lehman Engel, Lou Harrison, Jerome Moross, and E. Robert Schmitz. Recognition of Ives came about gradually. Foremost among Ives enthusiasts was pianist John Kirkpatrick, who began to play the "Concord" Sonata in the late twenties, finally giving the first full public hearing of "Concord" in 1939, following ten years of study and practice. This occasion proved to be a turning point in Ives's career. Kirkpatrick's continuing dedication to Ives's music as performer and editor assured further recognition and publication. More recently, the Charles Ives Society has been responsible for guiding and assigning editions and re-editions of the music.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Collection
relatedmaterial.p: MSS 14 HSR, Charles Ives Rare and Non-Commercial Sound Recordings.

odd.head: General
odd.p: The music manuscripts of Charles Ives are described in John Kirkpatrick's A Temporary Mimeographed Catalogue of the Music Manuscripts of Charles Ives (1960) and James B. Sinclair's A Descriptive Catalogue of the Music of Charles Ives (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1999).

odd.head: General
odd.p: Ives's writings are divided into the following categories: A. Music B. Politics C. Insurance, Fiction, Autobiography D. Miscellaneous

Ives himself made no such divisions. These have been made for practical purposes of storage, accessibility and retrieval and should be taken only as general categories. A work might well belong in more than one division. For example, Essays Before a Sonata, appropriately placed with music writings, should not be neglected by those interested in Ives's politics, philosophies and biography.
For additional information regarding Ives's writings, see also:
Ives, Charles E. Essays Before a Sonata, The Majority, and Other Writings. Edited by Howard Boatwright. New York: W.W. Norton & Company, Inc., Norton Library, 1970.
Ives, Charles E. Memos. Edited by John Kirkpatrick. New York: W.W. Norton & Company, Inc., 1972.
Materials in series II range from drafts and manuscripts toward published works to jottings and scraps of marginalia made on clippings and advertisements.
When "draft," "sketch," or "manuscript" is used, it is to be assumed without further indication that it is in Ives's hand.
An asterisk shows an item added after the initial microfilming. The item will be found in the additional microfilm reel rather than in sequence.
Within the body of the register, titles of published works will not be underlined, italicized, or in quotations unless the meaning is otherwise distorted.
In all cases when a manuscript or typescript is either a carbon copy or a photoduplication, it is indicated as: (copy)

odd.head: General
odd.p: Pages with technical information about a specific music work have been placed with the appropriate manuscripts rather than in II.A. For example: a Page on Thoreau is with the song, "Thoreau" in 6B(52), and pages relating to "Concord" are in Box 13 with the "Concord" Sonata manuscripts. In such cases, cross references have been made.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Folders 6 and 7 were reorganized by John Kirkpatrick 1980 Jul; therefore, their order differs from that of the microfilm.

odd.head: General
odd.p: As a rule, correspondence, both general and institutional, is to be found in III.A and III.B; exceptions have been made with letters relating to Ives's proposal toward a 20th Amendment, The Majority, Letter to Roosevelt, and Harding Election. Letters are identified by the institution or government office followed by the name of the individual signer in parenthesis.

odd.head: General
odd.p: The Charles Ives Papers are the major holding of correspondence to Ives. In several cases, individuals have supplied either the originals or copies of their correspondence from Ives, thereby completing their exchange. Ives often made drafts of his letters to be copied by Harmony or Edith Ives for sending. The drafts were saved and are interfiled chronologically with the appropriate correspondence.
When John Kirkpatrick sorted the correspondence, he divided it into two major categories:

The files are arranged alphabetically first, and then chronologically within each correspondence. There have been many situations where several different filing places would have been possible. In these instances, what was considered the most useful location was chosen, and cross references were made. Occasionally, the alphabetical rule by correspondent is suspended. For example, materials relating to the Third Violin Sonata, although signed by Ingolf Dahl, Henry Cowell, or New Music, are on file with the Sonata.
Programs are included in correspondence folders only when they are from the correspondent and relating to him, not to Charles Ives.

The use of "sketch" or "draft" indicates without further identification that it is in Ives's hand. However, the opposite prevails in the case of final letters sent from Ives to others. Since so many letters were copied by Harmony Ives, it is to be assumed that they are in her hand unless so indicated. Letters from others are to Charles Ives except where otherwise noted.
NOTE: an asterisk indicates that the item arrived into the collection after the microfilming. It will not be found in sequence on microfilm., but on the additional microfilm reel.
Additional Ives correspondence can be found in the following collections:
Yale University, Gilmore Music Library, John Kirkpatrick Papers
New York Public Library for the Performing Arts Library, John Becker Collection
New York Public Library for the Performing Arts Library, Henry Cowell Collection

did.unittitle: List of correspondence of Ives and Becker compiled by John Kirkpatrick

odd.head: General
odd.p: The correspondence dates from 1931 to 1963 when Harmony Ives was almost eighty-eight. Becker's side of the exchange along with drafts of letters to Becker kept by the Iveses are in folders 4 and 5. Interfiled are typed transcripts (by John Kirkpatrick) of Ives letters to Becker loaned to John Kirkpatrick by Mrs. Evelyn Becker. Folder 6 contains photocopies of Ives's letters; (excepting autograph letter signed Charles Ives 1939 Mar 30; this is the original) the originals are with the papers of John Becker at the New York Public Library.
The letters from Charles Ives to Becker number 42 (79 pages). There is one memo, one fragment, and two postcards.

odd.head: General
odd.p: The correspondence of Charles Ives to Herrmann is in the collection of Herrmann papers with his widow, Norma Shepard Herrmann, in London. Photocopies were made in 1979 by William Brooks. These are as follows: Nineteen letters, one original only in photocopy; one in Harmony Ives's hand signed "Charles;" one signed "Charles and Harmony Ives" in Harmony's hand; thirteen written and signed by Harmony; two written by Edith Ives and signed "Edith Ives for Charles Ives;" two written and signed by Edith. The dates cover two periods: 1936 Jul 18 to 1938 Oct (twelve letters); and 1945 Apr 22 to 1946 Sep 19 (six letters). One letter, from Edith, sent from Taormina, Italy is undated. This was probably written early 1933. These copies have been placed in the front of folder 30/4 preceding Herrmann's correspondence to Ives.
X.D/65/3; X.D/67/17/Library Correspondence and Gifts after 1955

The correspondence of Charles Ives to family members dating from 1880 were found by John Kirkpatrick in papers given him by Ives's cousin Amelia Van Wyck. They were added to these papers in 1979. (See 33/1-2).
For Harmony Ives with Yale Library see: III.B/36/8/Yale Music Library, X.D/67/17/Library Correspondence.

odd.head: General
odd.p: This register lists the correspondence from John Kirkpatrick to Charles Ives. Ives's letters to Kirkpatrick have been microfilmed; they can be found on the addenda microfilm reel. The originals now belong to the John Kirkpatrick Papers at Yale. Kirkpatrick's correspondence with others relating to Ives and his music can also be found in the John Kirkpatrick Papers.

These are the personal tax files of Harmony and Charles Ives.
Included are lists of deductions, charitable and otherwise, and all other correspondence relating to personal income tax.

odd.head: General
odd.p: There are eight scrapbooks: four large; four smaller in size. The larger scrapbooks were numbered by Ives. All follow a loose chronological order. For reasons of preservation, letters and other valuable items that could be removed without damage have been placed elsewhere in the Collection.

odd.head: General
odd.p: The diaries and notebooks were numbered by John Kirkpatrick. Photographs in "Our Book" (Box 45/7/D7) have been copied and can be found also in the Photograph Collection of this register, Series VI. For the history and full description of the Diaries, See John Kirkpatrick Catalogue, preface. Transcriptions may be found in the John Kirkpatrick Papers, Box 87, Folder 799.

odd.head: General
odd.p: All transcribed by John Kirkpatrick. Perhaps meant to be part of Memos.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection includes most of the existing iconographic material relating to Charles Ives. For other collections, see the Scott Fanton Museum, the MONY Library, and private collectors Earl Gilmore and James Burk.

In addition to the photographic materials given by Mrs. Ives to the Library along with the manuscripts and memorabilia in 1954, other items have been placed in this file by John Kirkpatrick and Vivian Perlis. Amelia Van Wyck, Ives's cousin, contributed family photographs and George Tyler, Ives's son-in-law, has been generous in allowing copies of photographs to be made from originals which are in the Ives house at West Redding.

odd.head: General
odd.p: There are 237 items in the collection (and some miscellaneous materials). Each item has been given a number. Two negatives and a 5 x 7 glossy print have been made for each photograph and labeled with the corresponding number. The prints are placed in three albums and are to be used for viewing and for photographic orders. The original materials are in box 46 of the Ives Papers and may be seen on request.

Original. If the original photograph is in the Ives Papers, this is indicated by the word "Original"; if it is elsewhere, the location is specified whenever that is known to us. (The term "original" is used loosely to describe first prints, snapshots, and early negatives.) Photographers' names are supplied when known along with permission, fee, and credit information.
Description/Information identifies the place and/or persons, the date of the photograph, and the occasion.

odd.head: General
odd.p: No systematic effort has been made to collect programs except for the earliest. This file includes programs from Ives's own collection and those donated by others at various times.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Programs and reviews were filed together until their number led to a division; therefore, a program may be found with a particular review in this file. As with the program file, no systematic attempt has been made to collect reviews. These have been taken from Ives's own collection and from donations by others.

odd.head: General
odd.p: No systematic attempt has been made to collect such material; this series includes those items donated to the library. It excludes doctoral dissertations which are in the general library collection and listed in Orbis.

odd.head: General
odd.p: In a music cabinet in the studio at West Redding are additional items of printed music by other composers either bought by or given to Ives. The drawers are numbered 1-62; some are empty. This listing conforms to the drawer numbers. It was made by Vivian Perlis in 1978.

The Banner
3 copies, more drawings of ladies- Evening News, Ives and Myrick Pamphlet The Spectator, clipping Danbury Evening News, clipping an article by Sarah Ives, Picture of string quintet, ad for Heigman Department Store, testimony of William Anderson, newspaper ad

odd.head: General
odd.p: Large collection of folders, envelopes, cover sheets used for storage and filing by Ives with autograph identifications and marginalia.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Large collection of folders formerly used by library with Kirkpatrick identifications and information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence and information relating to Ives Oral History Project. The tapes of interviews with sixty people who worked with or knew Ives may be found at the Library; copies with Oral History, American Music Project directed by Vivian Perlis.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Transcripts also with Oral History, American Music Project.
See also: Charles Ives Remembered, an Oral History by Perlis. New Haven: Yale University Press, 1974. Paperback: New York: W.W. Norton.

odd.p: Sub-series X.E is no longer in use
